title: Common East African Tourism Agenda outlined during East Africa Tourism Development ForumTravelandtourworld.com
text:
Common East African Tourism Agenda outlined during East Africa Tourism Development Forum Published on : Thursday, August 27, 2015
The East Africa Tourism Development Forum, the first of its kind, was held at Sarova Whitesands beach hotel in Mombasa from Aug 20-22. It was organised by the United Nations World Tourism Organisation and the Kenyan government.
The East Africa Tourism Development Forum brought together Tourism Ministers and representatives from East Africa and the Vanilla Islands to explore areas of further regional cooperation.
Regional tourism leaders and stakeholders gathered during the forum to identify opportunities to maximize sustainable tourism development through regional collaboration.
The forum was opened by the Deputy President of the Republic of Kenya, William Samoei Ruto who said that ‘tourism is a critical component of the East African economy and an important part of our common destiny.’
UNWTO Secretary-General, Taleb Rifai, showed the organisation’s confidence in the East African Community´s ability to position itself as a leading tourism destination.
The UNWTO Secretary General welcomed the recent introduction of the East Africa Tourist Visa, ‘which allows travel between Kenya, Rwanda and Uganda, boosting regional tourism and creating opportunities for tourists to explore the diversity of multiple destinations in the region.’
A future common East African Tourism Agenda was outlined during a Ministerial meeting held on the occasion of the Forum, revealed UNWTO in a press release. The press release further cited that The Ministers also agreed to work towards further mainstreaming tourism in the agenda of the African Union stressing that the sector can make a key contribution to the peace and development objectives of Africa.
The African Tourism Ministers of Seychelles, Sudan and Uganda, as well as senior officials from the Ministry of Tourism of Tanzania also participated in the Forum. They were joined by high-level representatives for the African Airlines Association (AFRAA), the East Africa Community (EAC), the International Air transport Association (IATA), and Kenya Airways.
